text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

In a world with increasing
competitive economic pressures

and global supply chains, it
is more critical than ever

for organizations to understand
their cost of doing business.

Even Santa Claus isn't
immune to the pressures
of global economics.

A combination of
greater volatility

in children's preferences
for more sophisticated toys,

increased supply chain
costs, and changes

in international trade policies
affecting import tariffs

forced Santa to evaluate
the unprecedented move

to outsource the production
of electronic toys.

Outsourcing would have
important implications,

including layoffs
and potential brand

erosion as they relinquish
control over toy quality.

Santa, like any other CEO,
would only consider it
if it made financial sense.
Should he outsource?

If he did, which of the bidders
should win the contract?

To make these
decisions, Santa needs

to obtain an accurate picture
of current toy production costs

and estimate how outsourcing
would change those costs.

Full costs for each
toy production line

must include all
costs associated

with acquiring materials,
including transportation,

insurance, tariffs, direct
costs of the elves labor,

and a portion of
overhead costs as they

relate to the production
of each type of toy.

To then compare the current
cost of producing toys in-house

with the prices
offered by each bidder,

Santa would need to know
which production costs would

no longer be incurred if
he accepted those bids.

As Santa knows, making
critical strategic decisions

requires comprehensive
costing systems, especially

in times of turbulence
and economic uncertainty.

Investing time and resources to
maintain a more sophisticated

costing system may
save organizations

from becoming uncompetitive
and ultimately,
financially unsustainable.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
